document:
# **Indian Penal Code: Sections on Assault and Criminal Force**

# Title: **Section 131: Punishment for Assault or Criminal Force Otherwise Than on Grave Provocation**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave

and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either

description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to

one thousand rupees, or with both.

## **Explanation 1:**

Grave and sudden provocation will not mitigate the punishment for an offence under this section:

- (a) If the provocation is sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for the offence.  

- (b) If the provocation is given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant, in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant.  

- (c) If the provocation is given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.  

## **Explanation 2:**

Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to mitigate the offence is a question of fact.

## **Section 132: Assault or Criminal Force to Deter Public Servant from Discharge of Duty**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in

the execution of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that

person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything

done or attempted to be done by such person in the lawful discharge of his duty, shall be

punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years,

or with fine, or with both.

## **Section 133: Assault or Criminal Force with Intent to Dishonour a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to
icl_document:
Physical altercations, even minor ones, can have legal consequences. If force is used unlawfully,
it may be punishable under the law.
document_outline:
This document outlines various legal provisions related to criminal force, explaining relevant statutes
through real-world scenarios. It aims to educate individuals on their rights and the legal consequences
of using force unlawfully.
icl_query_1: A man shoved a shopkeeper over pricing. The shopkeeper didn’t retaliate. Was the push illegal?
icl_response_1: Yes, this is an offense under Section 131, as force was used without grave provocation.
icl_query_2: My neighbor slapped me in a parking dispute. Can I take legal action?
icl_response_2: Yes, the slap is considered criminal force under Section 131, and legal action can be taken.
icl_query_3: At a wedding, my cousin threw a drink at another guest. Could this lead to legal trouble?
icl_response_3: Yes, this act falls under Section 131, as it constitutes criminal force.
icl_query_4: I pushed a pedestrian aside while cycling in frustration. Can I face legal trouble?
icl_response_4: Yes, using force in such a situation can be punishable under Section 131.
icl_query_5: My boss slapped my colleague for an error. Can my colleague file a complaint?
icl_response_5: Yes, under Section 131, the employer can be charged for using criminal force.

# **Indian Penal Code: Sections on Assault and Criminal Force**

# Title: **Section 131: Punishment for Assault or Criminal Force Otherwise Than on Grave Provocation**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave

and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either

description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to

one thousand rupees, or with both.

## **Explanation 1:**

Grave and sudden provocation will not mitigate the punishment for an offence under this section:

- (a) If the provocation is sought or voluntarily provoked by the offender as an excuse for the offence.  

- (b) If the provocation is given by anything done in obedience to the law, or by a public servant, in the lawful exercise of the powers of such public servant.  

- (c) If the provocation is given by anything done in the lawful exercise of the right of private defence.  

## **Explanation 2:**

Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to mitigate the offence is a question of fact.

## **Section 132: Assault or Criminal Force to Deter Public Servant from Discharge of Duty**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in

the execution of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that

person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything

done or attempted to be done by such person in the lawful discharge of his duty, shall be

punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years,

or with fine, or with both.

## **Section 133: Assault or Criminal Force with Intent to Dishonour a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to
icl_document:
Public servants, such as police officers and government officials, perform duties involving law
enforcement. Using force against them is a criminal offense.
document_outline:
This document outlines various legal provisions related to criminal force, explaining relevant statutes
through real-world scenarios. It aims to educate individuals on their rights and the legal consequences
of using force unlawfully.
icl_query_1: I pushed a traffic policeman in anger and drove away. Did I commit a crime?
icl_response_1: Yes, under Section 132, assaulting a public servant on duty is punishable.
icl_query_2: A shopkeeper grabbed a municipal worker to stop stall removal. Is this legal?
icl_response_2: No, preventing a public servant from their duty using force is an offense under Section 132.
icl_query_3: People shoved a government officer at a rally. Can they be arrested?
icl_response_3: Yes, this is an offense under Section 132.
icl_query_4: My friend tried to stop officials from seizing his shop physically. Can he be punished?
icl_response_4: Yes, his actions violate Section 132 and are punishable.
icl_query_5: Protesters pushed security guards to enter a government office. Is this a crime?
icl_response_5: Yes, under Section 132, assaulting public servants on duty is a crime.

## **Explanation 2:**

Whether the provocation was grave and sudden enough to mitigate the offence is a question of fact.

## **Section 132: Assault or Criminal Force to Deter Public Servant from Discharge of Duty**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in

the execution of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that

person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything

done or attempted to be done by such person in the lawful discharge of his duty, shall be

punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years,

or with fine, or with both.

## **Section 133: Assault or Criminal Force with Intent to Dishonour a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to
icl_document:
In some cases, force is used not to injure but to humiliate or degrade another person. The law
punishes such acts of dishonor.
document_outline:
This document outlines various legal provisions related to criminal force, explaining relevant statutes
through real-world scenarios. It aims to educate individuals on their rights and the legal consequences
of using force unlawfully.
icl_query_1: A man tore a woman’s scarf during an argument to insult her. Can she take legal action?
icl_response_1: Yes, this falls under Section 133, as force was used with intent to dishonor.
icl_query_2: A group paraded a man through the village to embarrass him. Is this against the law?
icl_response_2: Yes, under Section 133, using force to dishonor someone is a criminal offense.
icl_query_3: Someone threw ink on a journalist to shame him. Is this considered a crime?
icl_response_3: Yes, this act falls under Section 133.
icl_query_4: The groom’s family forced the bride's father to bow before them. Can they be punished?
icl_response_4: Yes, under Section 133, this is an offense.
icl_query_5: A group dragged a man out of a meeting to embarrass him. Can he file a complaint?
icl_response_5: Yes, this is punishable under Section 133.

icl_document:
Theft becomes more serious when force is used. If someone attempts to steal property another person
is carrying and uses force in the process, it is a criminal offense.
document_outline:
This document outlines various legal provisions related to criminal force, explaining relevant statutes
through real-world scenarios. It aims to educate individuals on their rights and the legal consequences
of using force unlawfully.
icl_query_1: A man snatched my aunt’s handbag and pushed her. What legal action can she take?
icl_response_1: This falls under Section 134, as force was used in an attempt to commit theft.
icl_query_2: Someone tried to grab my chain and hit me when I resisted. Is this a crime?
icl_response_2: Yes, this is an offense under Section 134.
icl_query_3: A thief grabbed a cash bag and punched a delivery boy who resisted. Can he be charged?
icl_response_3: Yes, this is a criminal offense under Section 134.
icl_query_4: Someone snatched a mobile phone at a festival using force. Can this be reported?
icl_response_4: Yes, this is an offense under Section 134.
icl_query_5: A thief shoved a vendor to take his money. Does this fall under any law?
icl_response_5: Yes, under Section 134, using force while attempting theft is a punishable crime.

# **Indian Penal Code: Sections on Assault and Criminal Force**

# Title: **Section 131: Punishment for Assault or Criminal Force Otherwise Than on Grave Provocation**

## **Section 132: Assault or Criminal Force to Deter Public Servant from Discharge of Duty**

done or attempted to be done by such person in the lawful discharge of his duty, shall be

punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years,

or with fine, or with both.

## **Section 133: Assault or Criminal Force with Intent to Dishonour a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to
icl_document:
Confining someone against their will is unlawful. If force is used to restrain or prevent a person
from moving freely, it can be legally punished.
document_outline:
This document outlines various legal provisions related to criminal force, explaining relevant statutes
through real-world scenarios. It aims to educate individuals on their rights and the legal consequences
of using force unlawfully.
icl_query_1: My landlord locked my brother inside his room over rent. Can we file a complaint?
icl_response_1: Yes, this is an offense under Section 135.
icl_query_2: A group physically blocked a man from leaving a meeting. Is this legal?
icl_response_2: No, this is wrongful confinement under Section 135.
icl_query_3: Mall security locked a customer in a room without reason. Can he take legal action?
icl_query_4: A group blocked my sister from leaving a house by standing in her way. Is this a crime?
icl_response_4: Yes, under Section 135, wrongful confinement with force is a crime.
icl_query_5: Protesters locked a journalist inside a vehicle to stop reporting. Can this be reported?
icl_response_5: Yes, this act is punishable under Section 135.

document:
dishonour that person, otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that

person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may

extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

## **Section 134: Assault or Criminal Force in Attempt to Commit Theft of Property Carried by a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting to commit

theft on any property which that person is then wearing or carrying, shall be punished with

imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine,

or with both.

## **Section 135: Assault or Criminal Force in Attempt to Wrongfully Confine a Person**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting wrongfully

to confine that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a

term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to five thousand

rupees, or with both.

## **Section 136: Assault or Criminal Force on Grave and Sudden Provocation**

Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person on grave and sudden

provocation given by that person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a

term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to one thousand

rupees, or with both.

For more details, refer to the official document:

Ministry of Home Affairs – Indian Penal Code
